action.action-desc: Mr. Tonko (for himself and Mr. Kennedy) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Education and the Workforce

form.official-title: To better integrate engineering education into kindergarten through grade 12 instruction and curriculum and to support research on engineering education.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Educating Tomorrow's Engineers Act.

title.header: Amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965

section.header: Academic standards, academic assessments, and accountability
section.text: Section 1111(b) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 6311(b)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (1), by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.header: Integration of engineering skills and practices into science standards
subparagraph.text: By not later than the 2016–2017 school year, each State plan shall demonstrate that the State has incorporated engineering design skills and practice into the State science challenging academic content standards and student academic achievement standards that are required under this paragraph.

paragraph.text: in paragraph (3)(C)(v)(II), by inserting (including, beginning not later than the 2016–2017 school year, engineering design skills and practices) after science.

section.header: Grants for State assessments and related activities
section.text: Section 6111(1) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7301(1)) is amended by inserting , including the integration of engineering concepts into science assessments, before and standards.

section.header: Teacher and principal training and recruiting fund
section.text: Section 2113 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 6613) is amended—

subparagraph.text: in paragraph (1), by striking 95 and inserting 85;
in paragraph (2), by striking and after the semicolon;
by redesignating paragraph (3) as paragraph (4); and
by inserting after paragraph (2) the following:

paragraph.text: reserve 10 percent of the funds made available through the grant to make subgrants in accordance with subsection (e); and
by redesignating subsections (e) and (f) as subsections (f) and (g), respectively; and
by inserting after subsection (d) the following:

subsection.header: STEM professional development and instructional materials grants
subsection.text: A State educational agency that receives a grant under this part shall use the funds described in subsection (a)(3) to award grants, on a competitive basis, to nonprofit organizations, and other entities, with expertise and a demonstrated record of success in STEM fields to enable such organizations and entities to develop and provide professional development and instructional materials for STEM in the State.

in subparagraph (C), by striking mathematics and science and inserting STEM; and
in paragraph (3), in the matter preceding subparagraph (A), by striking mathematics and science each place the term appears and inserting STEM;

section.text: Section 4205(a)(2) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7175(a)(2)) is amended by striking mathematics and science and inserting STEM.

Section 9101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7801) is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating paragraphs (37) through (43) as paragraphs (38) through (44), respectively; and

title.header: Amendments to the Education Science Reform Act of 2002

section.text: The Education Sciences Reform Act of 2002 (20 U.S.C. 9501 et seq.) is amended—

paragraph.text: in section 131(b)(1)(C) (20 U.S.C. 9531(b)(1)(C)), by striking mathematics, science, and inserting STEM (as defined in section 9101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7801)),; and

in section 133(a)(11) (20 U.S.C. 9533(a)(11)) by striking mathematics and science and inserting STEM (as defined in section 9101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7801)).

subsection.text: The Secretary of Education, acting through the Director of the Institute of Education Sciences, shall support, directly or through grants or contracts, research on engineering education, including studies and evaluations that—

paragraph.text: identify and assess how science inquiry and mathematical reasoning can be connected to engineering design in kindergarten through grade 12 curricula and teacher professional development;
identify best practices and promising innovations in the field of kindergarten through grade 12 engineering education; and
include any other information or assessments the Secretary of Education may require.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Education shall, based on the results of the research described in subsection (a), disseminate information and analysis to the public, and provide technical assistance to State educational agencies, on best practices and promising innovations in the field of kindergarten through grade 12 engineering education.
There are authorized to be appropriated to carry out this section such sums as may be necessary for each of fiscal years 2014 through 2018.
